AllowedURLs.title: Allowed URLs
AllowedURLs.tooltip: Specify the sites your users are allowed to access while in their work context. No other sites will be allowed. You may choose to configure either an allowed/blocked list, but not both. ​

ApplicationProxyRedirection.title: Application proxy redirection
ApplicationProxyRedirection.tooltip: Enable App proxy redirection to give users access to corporate links and on-premise web apps.

BlockedURLs.title: Blocked URLs
BlockedURLs.tooltip: Specify the sites that are blocked for your users while in their work context. All other sites will be allowed. You may choose to configure either an allowed/blocked list, but not both.

Bookmarks.tooltip: Enter a list of bookmarked URLs for your users to have available when using Microsoft Edge in their work context.​

HomepageURL.title: Homepage shortcut URL
HomepageURL.tooltip: Configure a homepage shortcut that will appear to users as the first icon beneath the search bar when they open a new tab in Microsoft Edge.​

PersonalContext.label: Redirect restricted sites to personal context
PersonalContext.tooltip: Configure if users should be allowed to transition to their personal context to open restricted sites.

DaysUntilForcedReboot.label: Number of days to wait before restart is enforced

QualityUpdateRelease.label: Expedite installation of quality updates if device OS version less than:

WindowsQualityUpdateProfile.infoBoxText: The only dedicated quality update control currently available other than the existing update rings policy for Windows 10 and later is the ability to expedite quality updates for devices that fall behind a specified patch level. Additional controls will be available in the future.
WindowsQualityUpdateProfile.licenseLearnMoreText: Learn more about pre-requisites and quality update policies.
WindowsQualityUpdateProfile.licenseWarningBoxText: Creating quality update policies requires specific licensing.
WindowsQualityUpdateProfile.warningBoxText: While expediting software updates can help decrease the time to get to compliance when necessary, it has a larger impact on end-user productivity. The chances that they will experience a restart during business hours is significantly increased.

TouchId1.android: On Android, you can allow using fingerprint identification instead of a PIN. Users are prompted to provide their fingerprints when they access this app with their work accounts.
TouchId1.iOS: On iOS/iPadOS devices, you can allow using fingerprint identification instead of a PIN. Users are prompted to provide their fingerprints when they access this app with their work accounts.
TouchId1.mac: On Mac devices, you can allow using fingerprint identification instead of a PIN. Users are prompted to provide their fingerprints when they access this app with their work accounts.

PolicySettings.allowWidgetContentSync:
Choose Block to prevent policy managed apps from saving data to app widgets. If you choose Allow, the policy managed app can save data to app widgets, if those features are supported and enabled within the policy managed app. 

 

Apps may provide additional configuration capability with app configuration policies. For more information, see the app's documentation.
PolicySettings.appSharingFromLevel1: Select one of the following options to specify the apps that this app can receive data from:
PolicySettings.appSharingFromLevel2: {0}: Only allow receiving data in org documents or accounts from other policy managed apps
PolicySettings.appSharingFromLevel3: {0}: Allow receiving data in org documents or accounts from any app
PolicySettings.appSharingFromLevel4: {0}: Do not allow receiving data in org documents or accounts from any app
PolicySettings.appSharingFromLevel5: {0}: Allow data transfer from any app and treat all incoming data without an user identity as Org data.
PolicySettings.appSharingToLevel1: Select one of the following options to specify the apps that this app can send data to:
PolicySettings.appSharingToLevel2: {0}: Only allow sending org data to other policy managed apps
PolicySettings.appSharingToLevel3: {0}: Allow sending org data to any app
PolicySettings.appSharingToLevel4: {0}: Do not allow sending org data to any app
PolicySettings.appSharingToLevel5: {0}: Only allow transfer only to other policy managed apps and file transfer to other MDM managed apps on enrolled devices
PolicySettings.appSharingToLevel6: {0}: Allow transfer only to other policy managed apps and filter OS Open-in/Share dialogs to only display policy managed apps
PolicySettings.assignmentFilterEdit1: If you apply assignment filters to this policy, the 'Device Management Type' property will apply in addition to the values specified for 'Target to apps on all device types' and 'Device types' on the 'Apps' page.
PolicySettings.assignmentFilterEdit2: Learn more about assigning App Protection policies.
PolicySettings.conditionalEncryption1: Select {0} to disable app encryption for internal app storage when device encryption is detected on an enrolled device.
PolicySettings.conditionalEncryption2: Note: Intune can only detect device enrollment with Intune MDM. External app storage will still be encrypted to ensure data cannot be accessed by unmanaged applications.
PolicySettings.contactSyncMac: If disabled, apps cannot save contacts to the native address book.
PolicySettings.contactsSync:
Choose Block to prevent policy managed apps from saving data to the device's native apps (like Contacts, Calendar and widgets), or to prevent the use of add-ins within the policy managed apps. If you choose Allow, the policy managed app can save data to the native apps or use add-ins, if those features are supported and enabled within the policy managed app.

Apps may provide additional configuration capability with app configuration policies. For more information, see the app's documentation.
PolicySettings.deviceTypeTargetingCreate1: Device type targeting has moved to the Assignments step in policy creation.
PolicySettings.deviceTypeTargetingEdit1: If you apply assignment filters to this policy, the 'Device Management Type' property will apply in addition to the values specified for 'Target to apps on all device types' and 'Device types' on the 'Apps' page.
PolicySettings.deviceTypeTargetingEdit2: To edit device management type targeting, reset 'Target to apps on all device types' = 'Yes'. Then create a MAM assignment filter with the desired values for 'Device Management Type'.
PolicySettings.deviceTypeTargetingHasMoved: Learn more about assigning App Protection Policies
PolicySettings.encryptionAndroid1: For apps that are associated with an Intune mobile application management policy, encryption is provided by Microsoft. Data is encrypted synchronously during file I/O operations according to the setting in the mobile application management policy. Managed apps on Android use AES-128 encryption in CBC mode utilizing the platform cryptography libraries. The encryption method is not FIPS 140-2 compliant. SHA-256 encryption is supported as an explicit instruction using the SigAlg parameter and will only work on devices 4.2 and above. Content on the device storage is always be encrypted.
PolicySettings.encryptionAndroid2: When you require encryption in your app policy, the end-user is required to setup and use a PIN to access their device.  If there is not a PIN set up for device access, the apps will not launch and the end-user will instead see a message, which says, “Your company has required that you must first enable a device PIN to access this application."
PolicySettings.encryptionMac1: For apps that are associated with an Intune mobile application management policy, encryption is provided by Microsoft. Data is encrypted synchronously during file I/O operations according to the setting in the mobile application management policy. Managed apps on Mac use AES-128 encryption in CBC mode utilizing the platform cryptography libraries. The encryption method is not FIPS 140-2 compliant. SHA-256 encryption is supported as an explicit instruction using the SigAlg parameter and will only work on devices 4.2 and above. Content on the device storage is always be encrypted.
PolicySettings.faceId1: Where applicable, you can allow the use of face identification instead of PIN. Users are prompted to provide face identification when they access this app with their work accounts.
PolicySettings.faceId2: Select Yes to allow face identification instead of a PIN for app access.
PolicySettings.managementLevelsAndroid1: Use this option to specify whether this policy applies to Android device administrator devices, Android Enterprise devices, or unmanaged devices.
PolicySettings.managementLevelsAndroid2: {0}: Unmanaged devices are devices where Intune MDM management has not been detected. This includes 3rd party MDM vendors.
PolicySettings.managementLevelsAndroid3: {0}: Intune-managed devices using the Android Device Administration API.
PolicySettings.managementLevelsAndroid4: {0}: Intune-managed devices using Android Enterprise Work Profiles or Android Enterprise Full Device Management.
PolicySettings.managementLevelsIos1: Use this option to specify whether this policy applies to MDM managed devices or unmanaged devices.
PolicySettings.managementLevelsIos2: {0}: Unmanaged devices are devices where Intune MDM management has not been detected. This includes 3rd party MDM vendors.
PolicySettings.managementLevelsIos3: {0}: Managed devices are managed by Intune MDM.
PolicySettings.minAppVersion: Define the required minimum App version number that a user should have to gain secure access to the app.
PolicySettings.minAppVersionWarning: Define the recommended minimum App version number that a user should have for secure access to the app.
PolicySettings.minOsVersion: Define the required minimum OS version number that a user should have to gain secure access to the app.
PolicySettings.minOsVersionWarning: Define the recommended minimum OS version number that a user should have to gain secure access to the app.
PolicySettings.minPatchVersion: Define the oldest required Android security patch level a user can have to gain secure access to the app.
PolicySettings.minPatchVersionWarning: Define the oldest recommended Android security patch level a user can have for secure access to the app.
PolicySettings.minSdkVersion: Define the required minimum Intune Application Protection Policy SDK version that a user should have to gain secure access to the app.
PolicySettings.requireAppPinDefault: Select Yes to disable the app PIN when a device lock is detected on an enrolled device.
PolicySettings.targetAllApps1: Use this option to target your policy to apps on devices of any management state.
PolicySettings.targetAllApps2: During policy conflict resolution this setting will be superseded if a user has policy targeted for a specific management state.
PolicySettings.touchId2: Select {0} to require fingerprint identity instead of a PIN for app access.

Tap.pinResetAfterNumberOfDays: Specify the number of days that must pass before the user must reset the PIN.
Tap.previousPinBlockCount: This setting specifies the number of previous PINs that Intune will maintain. Any new PINs must be different from those that Intune is maintaining.

WipPolicySettings.allowWindowsSearch: This will allow Windows Search to continue to search through encrypted data.
WipPolicySettings.authoritativeIpRanges: Enable this setting if you want to override Windows auto-detection of IP ranges.
WipPolicySettings.authoritativeProxyServers: Enable this setting if you want to override Windows auto-detection of proxy servers.
WipPolicySettings.dataRecoveryCert: A recovery certificate is a special Encrypting File System (EFS) certificate you can use to recover encrypted files if your encryption key is lost or damaged. You need to create the recovery certificate, and specify it here. More information is here
WipPolicySettings.enterpriseCloudResources:
Specify cloud resources to be treated as corporate and be protected with Windows Information Protection policy. Multiple resources can be specified by separating individual entries with the '|' character.

If you have a proxy configured in your company, then you can specify the proxy through which traffic to cloud resources you specified will be routed.

URL[,Proxy]|URL[,Proxy]

Without proxy: contoso.sharepoint.com|contoso.visualstudio.com
With proxy: contoso.sharepoint.com,proxy.contoso.com|contoso.visualstudio.com,proxy.contoso.com
WipPolicySettings.enterpriseIPv4Ranges:
Specify the IPv4 ranges that form your corporate network. These are used in conjunction with the Enterprise Network Domain Names that you specify to define your corporate network boundary.

This setting is required to have Windows Information Protection enabled.

Multiple ranges can be specified by separating individual entries with a comma.

For example: 3.4.0.1-3.4.255.255,192.168.1.1-192.168.255.255
WipPolicySettings.enterpriseIPv6Ranges:
Specify the IPv6 ranges that form your corporate network. These are used in conjunction with the Enterprise Network Domain Names that you specify to define your corporate network boundary.

Multiple ranges can be specified by separating individual entries with a comma.

For example: 2001:4898:dc05::-2001:4898:dc05:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff,2a01:110::-2a01:110:7fff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff
WipPolicySettings.enterpriseInternalProxyServers:
If you have a proxy configured in your company, then you can specify the proxy through which traffic to cloud resources specified in the Enterprise Cloud Resources settings are to be routed.

Multiple values can be specified by separating individual entries with a semi-colon.

For example: contoso.internalproxy1.com;contoso.internalproxy2.com
WipPolicySettings.enterpriseNetworkDomainNames:
Specify the DNS names that form your corporate network. These are used in conjunction with the IP ranges that you specify to define your corporate network boundary. Multiple values can be specified by separating individual entries with a comma.

This setting is required to have Windows Information Protection enabled.

For example: corp.contoso.com,region.contoso.com
WipPolicySettings.enterpriseProtectedDomainNames:
Specify the DNS names that form your corporate network. These are used in conjunction with the IP ranges that you specify to define your corporate network boundary. Multiple values can be specified by separating individual entries with a '|'.

This setting is required to have Windows Information Protection enabled.

For example: corp.contoso.com|region.contoso.com
WipPolicySettings.enterpriseProxyServers:
If you have external facing proxies in your corporate network, specify them here. When specifying a proxy server address, you should also specify the port through which traffic should be allowed and protected through Windows Information Protection.

Note: This list must not include servers in your Enterprise Internal Proxy Server list. Multiple values can be specified by separating individual entries with a semi-colon.

For example: proxy.contoso.com:80;proxy2.contoso.com:80
WipPolicySettings.maxInactivityTime1: Specifies the maximum amount of time (in minutes) allowed after the device is idle that will cause the device to become PIN or password locked. Users can select any existing timeout value less than the specified maximum time in the Settings app. Note the Lumia 950 and 950XL have a maximum timeout value of 5 minutes, regardless of the value set by this policy.
WipPolicySettings.maxInactivityTime2: 0 (default) - No timeout is defined. The default of '0' is interpreted as 'No timeout is defined.'
WipPolicySettings.maxPasswordAttempts1: This policy has different behaviors on the mobile device and desktop.
WipPolicySettings.maxPasswordAttempts2: On a mobile device, when the user reaches the value set by this policy, then the device is wiped.
WipPolicySettings.maxPasswordAttempts3: On a desktop, when the user reaches the value set by this policy, it is not wiped.Instead, the desktop is put on BitLocker recovery mode, which makes the data inaccessible but recoverable.If BitLocker is not enabled, then the policy cannot be enforced.
WipPolicySettings.maxPasswordAttempts4: Prior to reaching the failed attempts limit, the user is sent to the lock screen and warned that more failed attempts will lock their computer.When the user reaches the limit, the device automatically reboots and shows the BitLocker recovery page.This page prompts the user for the BitLocker recovery key.
WipPolicySettings.maxPasswordAttempts5: 0 (default) - The device is never wiped after an incorrect PIN or password is entered.
WipPolicySettings.maxPasswordAttempts6: Most secure value is 0 if all policy values = 0; otherwise, Min policy value is the most secure value.
WipPolicySettings.mdmDiscoveryUrl: Specify the URL for the MDM enrollment endpoint that users who enroll to MDM will use. By default, this is specified for Intune.
WipPolicySettings.minimumPinLength1: Integer value that sets the minimum number of characters required for the PIN. Default value is 4. The lowest number you can configure for this policy setting is 4. The largest number you can configure must be less than the number configured in the Maximum PIN length policy setting or the number 127, whichever is the lowest.
WipPolicySettings.minimumPinLength2: If you configure this policy setting, the PIN length must be greater than or equal to this number. If you disable or do not configure this policy setting, the PIN length must be greater than or equal to 4.
WipPolicySettings.name: The name of this network boundary
WipPolicySettings.neutralResources:
If you have authentication redirection endpoints in your company, specify those here. The locations specified here are considered to be either personal or corporate depending on the context of the connection prior to the redirection.

Multiple values can be specified by separating individual entries with a comma.

For example: sts.contoso.com,sts.contoso2.com
WipPolicySettings.passportForWork1: Value that sets Windows Hello for Business as a method for signing into Windows.
WipPolicySettings.passportForWork2: Default value is true.If you set this policy to false, the user cannot provision Windows Hello for Business except on Microsoft Entra joined mobile phones where provisioning is required.
WipPolicySettings.pinExpiration: The largest number you can configure for this policy setting is 730. The lowest number you can configure for this policy setting is 0. If this policy is set to 0, then the user’s PIN will never expire.
WipPolicySettings.pinHistory1: The largest number you can configure for this policy setting is 50. The lowest number you can configure for this policy setting is 0. If this policy is set to 0, then storage of previous PINs is not required.
WipPolicySettings.pinHistory2: The current PIN of the user is included in the set of PINs associated with the user account. PIN history is not preserved through a PIN reset.
WipPolicySettings.protectUnderLock: Protects app content while the device is in a locked state.
WipPolicySettings.protectionModeBlock: Block: Blocks enterprise data from leaving protected apps.
WipPolicySettings.protectionModeOff: Off: User is free to relocate data off of protected apps. No actions are logged.
WipPolicySettings.protectionModeOverride: Allow overrides: User is prompted when attempting to relocate data from a protected to a non-protected app. If they choose to override this prompt, the action will be logged.
WipPolicySettings.protectionModeSilent: Silent: User is free to relocate data off of protected apps. These actions are logged.
WipPolicySettings.revokeOnMdmHandoff: Added in Windows 10, version 1703. This policy controls whether to revoke the WIP keys when a device upgrades from MAM to MDM. If set to “Off”, the keys will not be revoked and the user will continue to have access to protected files after upgrade. This is recommended if the MDM service is configured with the same WIP EnterpriseID as the MAM service.
WipPolicySettings.revokeOnUnenroll: This will cause encryption keys to be revoked when a device un-enrolls from this policy.
WipPolicySettings.rmsTemplateForEdp: TemplateID GUID to use for RMS encryption. The Azure RMS template allows the IT admin to configure the details about who has access to RMS-protected file and how long they have access.
WipPolicySettings.showWipIcon: This will let the user know when they are acting in a corporate context, by overlaying an icon.
WipPolicySettings.useRmsForWip: Specifies whether to allow Azure RMS encryption for WIP.

Tooltips.requireAppPin:
Select Yes to disable the app PIN when a device lock is detected on an enrolled device.

Note: Intune cannot detect device enrollment with a third-party EMM solution on iOS/iPadOS.

ProfileDescription.androidDeviceOwnerDerivedCredentialAppAu: Set up a derived credential to enable certificate-based authentication in your org. This profile is for fully managed, dedicated, and corporate-owned work profile devices.
ProfileDescription.androidDeviceOwnerGeneral: Enable or disable device features, run apps on dedicated devices, control security, and more. This profile is for fully managed, dedicated, and corporate-owned work profile devices.
ProfileDescription.androidDeviceOwnerImportedPFX: Set up an imported public key pair (PKCS) certificate to enable S/MIME email encryption in your email profiles. This profile is for fully managed, dedicated, and corporate-owned work profile devices.
ProfileDescription.androidDeviceOwnerPKCS: Set up a public key pair (PKCS) certificate to enable certificate-based authentication in your org. This profile is for fully managed, dedicated, and corporate-owned work profile devices.
ProfileDescription.androidDeviceOwnerSCEP: Set up a Simple Certificate Enrollment Protocol (SCEP) certificate to enable certificate-based authentication in your org. This profile is for fully managed, dedicated, and corporate-owned work profile devices.
ProfileDescription.androidDeviceOwnerTrustedCertificate: Import the trusted root certificate from your Certification Authority and assign it to devices that use SCEP and PCKS certificates to authenticate with your org's resources. This profile is for fully managed, dedicated, and corporate-owned work profile devices.
ProfileDescription.androidDeviceOwnerVpn: Create and configure a VPN connection to your org's network. This profile is for fully managed, dedicated, and corporate-owned work profile devices.
ProfileDescription.androidDeviceOwnerWiFi: Set up a Wi-Fi network for people to access. This profile is for fully managed, dedicated, and corporate-owned work profile devices.
ProfileDescription.aospDeviceOwnerDevice: Enable or disable device features, control security, and more.
ProfileDescription.complianceAndroidDeviceOwner: This policy is for fully managed, dedicated, and corporate-owned work profile devices.
ProfileDescription.derivedCredentials: Set up a derived credential to enable certificate-based authentication in your org.
ProfileDescription.email: Configure an email server, SSL communication, and other built-in email settings.
ProfileDescription.iosCustom: The custom configuration template allows IT admins to assign settings that aren't built into Intune yet. For iOS and iPadOS devices, you can import a .mobileconfig file that you created using Apple Configurator 2 or Profile Manager.
ProfileDescription.iosDeviceFeatures: Device features control various aspects of the iOS/iPadOS device as a whole, such as the wallpaper, the dock layout, AirPrint settings, and web content filters.
ProfileDescription.iosGeneral: Device restrictions control security, hardware, data sharing, and more settings on the devices. For example, create a device restriction profile that manages access to the App store or restricts certain apps from being installed on the device.
ProfileDescription.macCustom: The custom configuration template allows IT admins to assign settings that aren't built into Intune yet. For macOS devices, you can import a .mobileconfig file that you created using Profile Manager or a different tool.
ProfileDescription.macCustomPreferences: Configure a preference file that uses the standard property list (.plist) format to define preferences for apps and the device.
ProfileDescription.macDeviceFeatures: Device features control various aspects of the macOS device as a whole, such as what items launch at login, the view of the login window, and AirPrint settings.
ProfileDescription.macEndpointProtection: Endpoint protection settings control security on macOS devices such as FileVault 2 encryption, Gatekeeper, and the Firewall.
ProfileDescription.macExtensions: Configuration of the extensions that are allowed to load on the device, and blocked from loading on the device.
ProfileDescription.macGeneral: Device restrictions control security, hardware, data sharing, and more settings on the devices. For example, create a device restriction profile that requires a device to have a password or manages what the device can sync from iCloud.
ProfileDescription.pKCS: Set up a public key pair (PKCS) certificate to enable certificate-based authentication in your org.
ProfileDescription.pKCSImport: Set up an imported public key pair (PKCS) certificate to enable S/MIME email encryption in your email profiles.
ProfileDescription.sCEP: Set up a Simple Certificate Enrollment Protocol (SCEP) certificate to enable certificate-based authentication in your org.
ProfileDescription.trustedRoot: Import the trusted root certificate from your Certification Authority and assign it to devices that use SCEP and PCKS certificates to authenticate with your org's resources.
ProfileDescription.vPN: Create and configure a VPN connection to your org's network.
ProfileDescription.wifi: Set up a Wi-Fi network for people to access.
ProfileDescription.wifiImport: Import and assign a Wi-Fi configuration profile that was previously exported to a file.
ProfileDescription.windows10Atp:
With Intune, you can use this device configuration profile to manage  Microsoft Defender for Endpoint onboarding and offboarding on Windows devices.

Did you know? Consider going to Endpoint security to create an endpoint security profile or security baseline profile to configure your common endpoint protection security features.

Endpoint security profiles provide a concise, curated set of security templates including Firewall, BitLocker, Antivirus and more. Security baseline profiles are templates with pre-configured settings values recommended by security experts.
ProfileDescription.windows10AtpStreamlinedOnboarding:
With Intune, you can use this device configuration profile to manage  Microsoft Defender for Endpoint onboarding and offboarding on Windows devices.

Did you know? Consider going to Endpoint security to create an endpoint security profile or security baseline profile to configure your common endpoint protection security features.

Endpoint security profiles provide a concise, curated set of security templates including Firewall, BitLocker, Antivirus and more. Security baseline profiles are templates with pre-configured settings values recommended by security experts.
ProfileDescription.windows10Custom:
Microsoft Intune includes many built-in settings to control different features on a device. You can also create custom profiles, which are created similar to built-in profiles. Custom profiles are great when you want to use device settings and features that aren't built in to Intune. These profiles include features and settings for you to control on devices in your organization. For example, you can create a custom profile that sets the same feature for every Windows device.

Did you know? Consider creating a Settings catalog profile instead. The Intune Settings catalog contains a lot of settings and values previously only available through a custom profile, in a native easy to search experience. More settings are continually being added.
ProfileDescription.windows10DeviceFirmwareConfigurationInte: When you use Intune to manage Autopilot devices, you can manage UEFI (BIOS) settings after they're enrolled, using the Device Firmware Configuration Interface (DFCI). DFCI enables Windows to pass management commands from Intune to UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface). In Intune, use this feature to control BIOS settings. Typically, firmware is more resilient to malicious attacks. It limits end users control over the BIOS, which is good in a compromised situation. For example, you use devices running Windows 10 or later in a secure environment, and want to disable the camera. You can disable the camera at the firmware-layer, so it doesn't matter what the end user does. Reinstalling the OS or wiping the computer won't turn the camera back on. In another example, lock down the boot options to prevent users from booting up another OS, or an older version of Windows that doesn't have the same security features.
ProfileDescription.windows10EndpointProtection:
With Intune, you can use device configuration profiles to manage common endpoint protection security features on Windows devices, including Firewall, BitLocker, Microsoft Defender and encryption.

Did you know? Consider going to Endpoint security to create an endpoint security profile or security baseline profile to configure your common endpoint protection security features.

Be sure to try the Bitlocker encryption report for a comprehensive view of encryption status of all enrolled devices.

Endpoint security profiles provide a concise, curated set of security templates including Firewall, BitLocker, Antivirus and more. Security baseline profiles are templates with pre-configured settings values recommended by security experts.
ProfileDescription.windows10General:
Intune includes device restriction policies that help administrators control Windows devices. These restrictions let you control a wide range of settings and features to protect your organization's resources. For example, administrators can set a minimum password length, and block simple passwords.

Did you know? Consider going to Endpoint security to create an endpoint security profile or security baseline profile to configure your common endpoint protection security features.

Endpoint security profiles provide a concise, curated set of security templates including Firewall, BitLocker, Antivirus and more. Security baseline profiles are templates with pre-configured settings values recommended by security experts.
ProfileDescription.windows10Kiosk: On devices running Windows 10 or later, use Intune to run devices as a kiosk, sometimes known as a dedicated device. A device in kiosk mode can run one app, or run many apps. You can show and customize a start menu, add different apps, including Win32 apps, add a specific home page to a web browser, and more. This feature applies to: Windows 10 and later and Windows Holographic for Business
ProfileDescription.windows10NetworkBoundary: When using Microsoft Defender Application Guard and Microsoft Edge, you can protect your environment from sites that aren't trusted by your organization. This feature is called a network boundary. It allows you to add network domains, IPV4 and IPv6 ranges, proxy servers, and more to your network boundary. Items in this boundary are trusted.
ProfileDescription.windows10SecureAssessmentProfile: Education profiles in Intune are designed for students to take a test or exam on devices. This feature includes the Take a Test app and settings to add a test URL, choose how end-users sign in to the test, and more.  When the user signs in, the Take a Test app automatically opens with the test you entered. No other apps can run on the device while the test is in progress.
ProfileDescription.windows10SharedPC: Devices that have multiple users are called shared devices, and are a common part of mobile device management (MDM) solutions. Using Microsoft Intune, you can customize shared devices running the following platforms: Windows 10 Professional and newer,  Windows 10 Enterprise and newer, Windows Holographic for Business, such as the HoloLens.  For example, schools have devices that are typically used by many students. With this setting, the school Intune administrator can turn on the Shared PC feature to allow one user at a time. Students can't switch between different signed-in accounts on the device. When the student signs out, you also choose to remove all user-specific settings. End users can sign in to these shared devices with a guest account. After users sign in, the credentials are cached. As they use the device, end-users only get access to features you allow. For example, you choose when the device goes in to sleep mode, if users can see and save files locally, enable or disable power management settings, and more. You also control if the guest account deletes when the user signs-off, or delete inactive accounts when a threshold is reached.
ProfileDescription.windows10TeamGeneral: Intune includes device restriction policies that help administrators control Windows 10 Team devices. These restrictions let you control settings and features to protect your organization's resources such as controlling the display of meeting information on the welcome screen or preventing waking the screen when someone enters the room.
ProfileDescription.windowsDeliveryOptimization: Delivery Optimization settings for your devices running Windows 10 or later can help reduce bandwidth consumption when those devices download applications and updates.
ProfileDescription.windowsDomainJoin: Many environments use on-premises Active Directory (AD). When AD domain-joined devices are also joined to Microsoft Entra ID, they're called Microsoft Entra hybrid joined devices. Using Windows Autopilot, you can enroll Microsoft Entra hybrid joined devices in Intune. To enroll, you also need a Domain Join configuration profile. A Domain Join configuration profile includes on-premises Active Directory domain information. When devices are provisioning (and typically offline), this profile deploys the AD domain details so devices know which on-premises domain to join. If you don't create a domain join profile, these devices might fail to deploy.
ProfileDescription.windowsEditionUpgrade: As part of your mobile device management (MDM) solution, you may want to upgrade your Windows 10/11 devices. For example, you want to upgrade your Windows 10/11 Professional devices to Windows 10/11 Enterprise. Or, you want the device to switch out of S mode. Windows 10/11 S mode is designed for security and performance. You can use Intune to switch out of S mode. Switching out of S mode is one way. And once you switch out of S mode, you can't go back to Windows 10/11 S mode. This feature applies to: Windows 10 and later, Windows 10 1809 or later for S mode and Windows Holographic for Business. These features are available in Intune, and are configurable by the administrator. Intune uses configuration profiles to create and customize these settings for your organization's needs. After you add these features in a profile, you can then push or deploy the profile to devices running Windows 10 or later in your organization. When you deploy the profile, Intune automatically upgrades the devices or switches out of S mode.
ProfileDescription.windowsHealthMonitoring: Microsoft can collect event data, and provide recommendations to improve performance on your Windows devices. Endpoint Analytics analyzes this data, and can recommend software, help improve startup performance, and fix common support issues. In Intune, you can create a Windows Health Monitoring device configuration profile to enable this data collection, and then deploy this profile to your devices. Use this profile as part of your mobile device management (MDM) solution to optimize your Windows devices.
ProfileDescription.windowsIdentityProtection:
With Intune, you can use this device configuration profile to manage Windows Hello for Business settings on Windows devices.

Did you know? Consider going to Endpoint security to create an endpoint security profile or security baseline profile to configure your common endpoint protection security features.

Endpoint security profiles provide a concise, curated set of security templates including Firewall, BitLocker, Antivirus and more. Security baseline profiles are templates with pre-configured settings values recommended by security experts.

This includes all supervised devices.

SettingDetails.allowAllTrustedAppsSideloadingDescriptio: Specifies whether apps from Appx packages signed with a trusted certificate can be sideloaded.

SettingDetails.allowEncryptedDataAndStoreAppsToAppearIn: Allow encrypted data and store apps to appear in Windows Search (No recommended).
Allow encrypted data and store apps to appear in Windows search results

SettingDetails.allowUnmanagedToReadManagedContactsDescr: An unmanaged app, such as the device's built-in contacts app, can access contact info in a managed app, such as Outlook. Available with iOS 12.0 and later.

SettingDetails.allowVisitedSitesCookiesOption: Allow cookies from visited web sites
SettingDetails.allowWindows11UpgradeDescription: Set to upgrade eligible Windows 10 devices to latest Windows 11 release.

SettingDetails.alternativeStartLayoutDescription: Import a custom XML layout to change the Start layout display order and tile size.
SettingDetails.alwaysOnVPNToolTip: When enabled, the device automatically connects to the VPN. It'll stay connected or will automatically reconnect when the device restarts or changes networks.​
SettingDetails.androidAppManagementHeaderName: Specify apps to allow or block on Samsung KNOX devices.
SettingDetails.androidAppsAllowedToBeInstalled: Apps allowed to be installed (Samsung KNOX Standard only)
SettingDetails.androidAppsAllowedToBeInstalledtHeaderNa: Specify the apps that users can install. Users will not to be able to install apps that are not on the list.
SettingDetails.androidAppsBlockedFromLaunch: Apps blocked from launching (Samsung KNOX Standard only)

Note that you will need to approve the app in the Managed Google Play Store, sync the app to Intune, and deploy it in order for it to be installed.
SettingDetails.androidDeviceOwnerCustomPasswordDescript: Create a device passcode for dedicated devices only. Can be 4-16 characters and contain numbers, letters, and special characters.
SettingDetails.androidDeviceOwnerLocateDeviceLostModeEn: Allow admin-initiated geolocation of lost or stolen devices. When you allow this, end users will receive a one-time notification stating that Intune has been granted location permissions.
SettingDetails.androidDeviceOwnerLocateDeviceUserlessDi: Block admin-initiated geolocation of lost or stolen devices​.
SettingDetails.androidElevenAndBelowPasswordHeaderDescr: These settings work for devices running Android 11 or earlier.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseAlwaysOnVpnClientPackag: Enter the package ID of the app in the Google Play store. For example, if the URL for the app in the Play store is https://play.google.com/store/details?id=com.contosovpn.android.prod, the package ID would be com.contosovpn.android.prod.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseAlwaysOnVpnLinkDescript: Learn more about configuring always-on VPN for Android Enterprise.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseAlwaysOnVpnLinkName: Always-on VPN can be configured in device restrictions.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseDeviceOwnerAlwaysOnVpnE: Set a VPN client to automatically connect and reconnect to the VPN whenever possible. Choose Disabled to disable always-on VPN for all VPN clients on device. Only one VPN client can be configured for always-on VPN on a given device, so be sure to have no more than one always-on VPN policy deployed to a single device.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseDeviceOwnerAlwaysOnVpnL: Enabling this forces all network traffic through the VPN tunnel. If a connection to the VPN can't be established, no network traffic will be allowed.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseDeviceSettingsBlockedDe: By default, users can access the Settings app while in kiosk mode.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseGlobalProxyExcludedHost: Semicolon separated list of host names for which the proxy is bypassed. The host names may contain wildcards such as *.example.com.
SettingDetails.androidEnterprisePowerButtonActionsBlock: By default, when a user holds down the power button on a device, they're shown power options such as Restart and Power off. Hiding these options prevent users from accidentally or intentionally shutting down devices.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseRequiredPasswordTypeDes: Set the password’s complexity requirements. Additional password requirements will become available based on your selection. Learn more about password requirements.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseStatusBarDescription: For devices running OS 9+, optionally allow end-users to access the device status bar and/or to receive notifications from the status bar. By default, the status bar and notifications are disabled on the device.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseSystemErrorWarningsEnab: By default, system warnings about crashed or unresponsive apps aren't shown onscreen to the user. Instead, when one of these events occurs, the system forces the app to close.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseSystemNavigationDescrip: For devices running OS 9+, optionally allow end-users to access the device home and overview buttons. By default, the device home and overview buttoms are disabled on the device.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseWorkProfileAlwaysOnVpnC: The specified VPN client must be installed on the device, and it must support per-app VPN in work profiles; otherwise, an error will occur. Note that you will need to approve the app in the Managed Google Play Store, sync the app to Intune, and deploy it in order for it to be installed in the user's work profile.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseWorkProfileAlwaysOnVpnE: Set a VPN client in the work profile to automatically connect and reconnect to the VPN whenever possible. Choose Disabled to disable always-on VPN for all VPN clients in the work profile. Only one VPN client can be configured for always-on VPN on a given device, so be sure to have no more than one always-on VPN policy deployed to a single device.
SettingDetails.androidEnterpriseWorkProfileAlwaysOnVpnL: Enabling this forces all network traffic for the work profile through the VPN tunnel. If a connection to the VPN can't be established, no network traffic will be allowed in the device's work profile.
SettingDetails.androidGeneralKiosk: These settings apply to Samsung KNOX Standard devices only.
SettingDetails.androidHiddenApps: Apps hidden from user (Samsung KNOX Standard only)
SettingDetails.androidHiddenAppsHeaderName: Specify the apps that will be hidden on the device. Users cannot discover or run these apps.
SettingDetails.androidNineAndBelowPasswordHeader: Android 9 and earlier or Samsung Knox
SettingDetails.androidNineAndBelowPasswordHeaderDescrip: These settings work for devices running Android 9 or earlier, and will also work on all Samsung Knox devices running any Android OS version.
SettingDetails.androidPasswordHeader: Require a password to unlock the device. If not configured, the use of passwords is optional, and left up to the user to configure.
SettingDetails.androidRestrictedKiosk: These settings apply to Samsung KNOX Standard devices running Android 10 or earlier only.
SettingDetails.androidTRDeprecation: Trusted certificates can no longer install on devices that run Android 11 or later, except for Samsung Knox devices. If you use SCEP certificate profiles, you must continue to create and deploy a trusted certificate profile and associate it with the SCEP certificate profile, but you must manually deliver the trusted root certificate to those devices.
SettingDetails.androidTenAndAbovePasswordHeaderDescript: These settings work for devices running Android 10 or later.
SettingDetails.androidTenDeprecationInfoBox: Beginning in October 2020, some settings will not be supported on Android devices that are running Android 10 and later and are not Samsung Knox. These settings are labeled with Android 9 and earlier or Samsung Knox. Click to learn more.
SettingDetails.androidTrustedServerCertificateNamesDesc: This is the DNS name used in the certificate presented by the Radius Server during client authentication to the Wifi access point. If you have multiple Radius servers which have the same DNS suffix in their fully qualified domain name then the suffix alone may also be used. This allows devices to trust the server certificate presented to them. Learn more.
SettingDetails.androidTwelveAndAbovePasswordHeaderDescr: These settings work for devices running Android 12 or later.
SettingDetails.androidTwelveDeprecationInfoBox: Beginning in November 2022, some settings are not supported on Android devices that are running Android 12 and later. These settings are labeled with Android 11 and earlier. Click to learn more.
SettingDetails.androidZebraMxConfigurationFileXmlName: Choose a valid Zebra MX XML file
SettingDetails.anyDNSAddressesInList: Use the following DNS servers to resolve the domains you entered (optional)
SettingDetails.appComplianceListName: Apps to allow or restrict on device
SettingDetails.appIdentifierDescription: For desktop, use the file path; for universal, use the Package Family Name.
SettingDetails.appManagementMSIAllowUserControlOverInst: This policy setting permits users to change installation options that typically are available only to system administrators. The security features of Windows Installer prevent users from changing installation options typically reserved for system administrators, such as specifying the directory to which files are installed. If enabled, installations that may otherwise be stopped due to a security violation would be permitted to continue. Default: disabled.
SettingDetails.appManagementMSIAlwaysInstallWithElevate: This policy setting directs Windows Installer to use elevated permissions when it installs any program on the system. If you enable this policy setting, privileges are extended to all programs. This enables users to install programs that require access to directories that the user might not have permission to view or change, including directories on highly restricted computers. Default: disabled.
SettingDetails.appManagementPackageFamilyNamesToLaunchA:
This policy allows the IT admin to specify a list of applications that users can run after logging on to the device.​
    For this policy to work, the Windows apps need to declare in their manifest that they will use the start up task
Enter a semicolon-delimited list of Windows apps Package Family Names
SettingDetails.appManagementUninstallBuiltInAppsDesc: Indicates whether or not to uninstall a fixed list of built-in Windows apps.
SettingDetails.appNonComplianceTypeDescription: We recommend asking your users to accept a Terms of Use, to acknowledge that apps on their device, including personal apps, will be evaluated, and noncompliant apps will be reported to the IT admin.
SettingDetails.appNonComplianceTypeName: Evaluate specified user installed applications on devices
SettingDetails.appReportCountofUserInstalledAppsName: Report device compliance based on installed apps
SettingDetails.applePersonalizedAdsBlockedDescription: Available for devices running iOS/iPadOS 14.0 or later.
SettingDetails.applicationGuardAllowFileSaveOnHostDescr: Allow users to download files from the virtualized browser onto the host operating system​.
SettingDetails.applicationGuardAllowFileSaveOnHostName: Download files to host file system
SettingDetails.applicationGuardAllowPersistenceDescript: Allow user data (e.g., passwords, favorites, and cookies) that is created during an Application Guard virtual browsing session to be saved.
SettingDetails.applicationGuardAllowPrintToDescription: Configure what content can be printed from unapproved websites in the Application Guard virtual browser.
SettingDetails.applicationGuardAllowVirtualGPUDescripti: Load graphics-intensive websites faster when working within the Application Guard virtual browsing session by enabling access to a virtual graphics processing unit.
SettingDetails.applicationGuardAuditingDescription: Collect logs for events that occur within an Application Guard virtual browsing session.
SettingDetails.applicationGuardBlockNonEnterpriseConten: Block content from unapproved websites from loading.
SettingDetails.applicationGuardClipboardAllowBothWayNam: Allow copy and paste between PC and browser
SettingDetails.applicationGuardClipboardAllowBrowserToP: Allow copy and paste from browser to PC only
SettingDetails.applicationGuardClipboardAllowPCToBrowse: Allow copy and paste from PC to browser only
SettingDetails.applicationGuardClipboardBehaviorDescrip: Choose what copy and paste actions are allowed from the local PC and an Application Guard virtual browser.
SettingDetails.applicationGuardClipboardBlockBothWayNam: Block copy and paste between PC and browser
SettingDetails.applicationGuardEnabledDescription: Application Guard opens unapproved sites in a Hyper-V virtualized browsing container.
SettingDetails.applicationGuardEnabledOptionsDescriptio: If enabled for Edge, Application Guard opens unapproved sites in a Hyper-V virtualized browsing container.
SettingDetails.applicationGuardInstallationText: This profile will install a Win32 component to activate Application Guard. End-users will need to restart the targeted devices to complete the successful installation and application of this profile.
SettingDetails.applicationGuardPrintFromVirtualBrowserD: Allow printing content from unapproved websites in the Application Guard virtual browser.
SettingDetails.appsActivateAboveLockScreenDescription:
This policy setting specifies whether Windows apps can be activated by voice when the screen is locked.

If allowed, apps can be activated by voice from the lock screen and users in your organization cannot change it.

If blocked, Windows apps are not allowed to be activated by voice from the lock screen and users in your organization cannot change it.

If left not configured, users in your organization can decide whether Windows apps can be activated from the lock screen by voice using Settings > Privacy on the device.
SettingDetails.appsActivateAboveLockScreenName: Voice activate apps from locked screen
SettingDetails.appsAutoUpdatePolicyDescription: Devices check for app updates daily. The default behavior is to let device users decide. They’ll be able to set their preferences in the managed Google Play app.
SettingDetails.appsPageDescription: Block access to Apps in Settings app.
SettingDetails.appsRecommendSkippingFirstUseHintsDescri: Enable a suggestion to apps that they skip their user tutorials and any introductory hints when they first start up, if applicable.
SettingDetails.associatedDomainsAppIdDescription: App ID typically takes the format <team ID>.<bundle ID>.
SettingDetails.associatedDomainsDomainsListDescription: Must be in the format <service type>:<domain>. Domain must be a fully qualified hostname, like www.example.com.
SettingDetails.associatedDomainsEnableDirectDownloadsDe: When enabled, the domain can download data directly instead of going through a content delivery network (CDN). Available for macOS 11 and later.
SettingDetails.associatedDomainsTableDescription: Can be used with SSO redirect-type extension, universal links, and password autofill on macOS 10.15+.
SettingDetails.authenticationAllowSecondaryDeviceDescri: Allow the use of Windows Hello companion devices for authenticating with Windows
SettingDetails.authenticationMethodDescription: Select how you want users to authenticate to the email server. Use certificates to provide the most secure and seamless experience for end users.
SettingDetails.authenticationMethodIKEv2Description: Select whether to authenticate using EAP or machine certificates.
SettingDetails.authenticationMethodTLSDescription: When you select Certificates, select one of the certificate profiles (SCEP or PKCS) that is also deployed to the device. This is the identity certificate that is presented by the device to the server.
SettingDetails.authenticationMethodTTLSDescription: When you select Certificates, select one of the certificate profiles (SCEP or PKCS) that is also deployed to the device. This is the identity certificate that is presented by the device to the server.
SettingDetails.authenticationPreferredAzureADTenantDoma: Enable user to sign in without typing the domain name.
SettingDetails.authenticationTransformAlgorithmDescript: Hash algorithm to be used during child (quick mode) security association negotiation. Value must match VPN server settings.
SettingDetails.authenticationWebSignInDescription: Allow the web credential provider for sign-in.
SettingDetails.authorizedAppRulesDescription: Apply authorized firewall rules in the local store to be recognized and enforced.
SettingDetails.authorizedAppRulesName: Authorized application Windows Firewall rules from the local store
SettingDetails.autoDetectIPRangesDescription: Windows can detect IP ranges on domain joined devices that are connected to the enterprise network. If you wish to prevent the auto-detection of IP ranges, then enable this option to force Windows to treat the IP ranges you specified in the network boundary definition as the authoritative list of IP ranges and to not perform any additional detection.
SettingDetails.autoDetectIPRangesName: Enterprise IP Ranges list is authoritative (do not auto-detect)
SettingDetails.autoDetectProxiesDescription: Windows can detect proxy servers on domain joined devices that are connected to the enterprise network. If you wish to prevent the auto-detection of proxy servers, then enable this option to force Windows to treat the proxy servers you specified in the network boundary definition as the authoritative list of proxy servers and to not perform any additional detection.
SettingDetails.autoDetectProxiesName: Enterprise Proxy Servers list is authoritative (do not auto-detect)
SettingDetails.autoInstallAndRebootAtMaintenanceTimeOpt: Auto install and restart at maintenance time
SettingDetails.autoInstallAndRebootAtScheduledTimeOptio: Auto install and restart at a scheduled time
SettingDetails.autoInstallAndRebootAtTimeDescription: Select automation update installation day and time
SettingDetails.autoInstallAndRebootAtTimeName: Install updates and reboot at scheduled time
SettingDetails.autoInstallAndRebootDayDescription: Select install day for scheduled updates
SettingDetails.autoInstallAndRebootTimeDescription: Select install time for scheduled updates
SettingDetails.autoInstallAndRebootWithoutEndUserContro: Auto install and reboot without end-user control
SettingDetails.autoRestartNotificationDismissalDescript: Specify the method by which the auto-restart required notification is dismissed.
SettingDetails.autoRestartNotificationDismissalName: Require user approval to dismiss restart notification
SettingDetails.autoUnlockBlockedDescription: Blocks users from unlocking their device with Apple Watch. Available for devices running iOS and iPadOS versions 14.5 or later.
SettingDetails.automatedDeviceEnrollmentHeaderDescripti: These settings work for supervised devices that were enrolled in Intune using Apple School Manager or Apple Business Manager with automated device enrollment (formerly DEP). This includes devices supervised through Apple Configurator.

These settings work for devices that were enrolled in Intune using Apple School Manager or Apple Business Manager with automated device enrollment (formerly DEP). This includes all supervised devices.
SettingDetails.automaticUpdateBehaviorDescription: Manage automatic update behavior to scan, download, and install updates.
SettingDetails.automaticUpdateFrequencyDescription: Scheduled the update installation on the weeks of the month
SettingDetails.automaticUpdatesDescription: Windows automatically runs update activites during idle periods (maintenance times). Users can override this behavior.
SettingDetails.automaticUpdatesSupervisedLearnMoreTextA: Learn more about update policies settings
SettingDetails.automaticUpdatesSupervisedName: Create a profile to force targeted devices to scan and install the latest iOS updates. Updates will only apply to supervised iOS devices.
SettingDetails.automaticVPNStory: Select the type of Automatic VPN you would like to use. The type of VPN cannot be changed after the policy is saved. All other attributes can still be changed.
SettingDetails.azureOperationalInsightsDescription: Software-as-a-service (Saas) solution in Microsoft Operations Management Suite (OMS) to let admins collect, store, and analyze log data from Windows 10 Team devices.
SettingDetails.backgroundWallpaperDescription: Customize the appearance of the screen background for assigned groups.
SettingDetails.batteryLevelTurnOnEnergySaverBatteryDesc:
This policy setting allows you to specify battery charge level at which Energy Saver is turned on when the device is powered by a battery.​
If you enable this policy setting, you must specify a percentage value that indicates the battery charge level. Energy Saver is automatically turned on at (and below) the specified battery charge level.​
If you disable or do not configure this policy setting, users control this setting.​
SettingDetails.batteryLevelTurnOnEnergySaverName: Battery​ level to turn Energy Saver on
SettingDetails.batteryLevelTurnOnEnergySaverPluggedInDe:
This policy setting allows you to specify battery charge level at which Energy Saver is turned on when the device is plugged in.​
If you enable this policy setting, you must specify a percentage value that indicates the battery charge level. Energy Saver is automatically turned on at (and below) the specified battery charge level.​
If you disable or do not configure this policy setting, users control this setting.​
SettingDetails.bitLockerAllowStdUsersEncryptAADJoinDesc: Allow users without Administrative rights the ability to enable BitLocker encryption on the local machine. This setting only applies to Microsoft Entra joined devices.
SettingDetails.bitLockerAllowStdUsersEncryptAADJoinName: Allow standard users to enable encryption during Microsoft Entra join
SettingDetails.bitLockerBaseConfigureEncryptionMethodsD: Selecting "Enable" allows you to configure the encryption methods for OS drives, fixed data-drives and removable data-drives. By selecting "Not configured", BitLocker will use the default encryption method for the drive.
SettingDetails.bitLockerBaseSettingsDescription: Base settings are universal BitLocker settings for all types of data drives.  These settings only apply to Windows 10/11 Enterprise, Windows 10/11 Education and Windows 10 Mobile.
SettingDetails.bitLockerDisableWarningForOtherDiskEncry: This setting prompts for any third party disk encryption on end users' machines. Selecting "Block" will disable the warning prompt for other disk encryption, and is required to allow standard users to enable encryption. Selecting "Not configured" will warn the end user that enabling BitLocker while third party encryption is in use will render the device unusable.
SettingDetails.bitLockerEnableStorageCardEncryptionOnMo: Selecting "Require" will encrypt the storage card of the mobile device.
SettingDetails.bitLockerEncryptDeviceDescription: Selecting "Require" will enable BitLocker device encryption. Depending on device hardware and Windows version, end users may be asked to confirm there is no third party encryption on their device. Turning on Windows encryption while third party encryption is in use will render the device unstable.
SettingDetails.bitLockerFixedDriveSettingsDescription: These settings apply specifically to fixed data drives. These settings only apply to Windows 10/11 Enterprise, Windows 10/11 Education and Windows 10 Mobile
SettingDetails.bitLockerFixedDriveWriteAccessDescriptio: Selecting "Block" will block data write to any fixed data-drive that is not protected by BitLocker. Selecting "Not configured" will allow data to be written to unencrypted fixed data-drives.
SettingDetails.bitLockerFixedDriveWriteAccessName: Write access to fixed data-drive not protected by BitLocker
SettingDetails.bitLockerRecoveryOptionsAfterRecoveryInf: Prevent users from enabling BitLocker unless the computer successfully backs up the BitLocker recovery information to Microsoft Entra ID. Selecting "Require" will ensure the recovery keys are successfully stored in Microsoft Entra ID before enabling encryption. By selecting "Not configured", a device may become encrypted without recovery information stored in Microsoft Entra ID.
Store recovery information in Microsoft Entra ID before enabling BitLocker
SettingDetails.bitLockerRecoveryOptionsHideDescription: Block users from specifying recovery options when they turn on BitLocker.
SettingDetails.bitLockerRecoveryOptionsHideName: Recovery options in the BitLocker setup wizard
SettingDetails.bitLockerRecoveryOptionsInformationToSto: Configure what pieces of BitLocker recovery information are stored in Microsoft Entra ID.
BitLocker recovery Information stored to Microsoft Entra ID
SettingDetails.bitLockerRecoveryOptionsKeyDescription: Configure if users are allowed, required or not allowed to generate a 256-bit recovery key.
SettingDetails.bitLockerRecoveryOptionsPasswordAndKey: Backup recovery passwords and key packages
SettingDetails.bitLockerRecoveryOptionsPasswordDescript: Configure if users are allowed, required or not allowed to generate a 48-digit recovery password.
SettingDetails.bitLockerRecoveryOptionsSaveToStoreDescr: Enable BitLocker recovery information to be stored in Microsoft Entra ID.
SettingDetails.bitLockerRecoveryOptionsSaveToStoreName: Save BitLocker recovery information to Microsoft Entra ID
SettingDetails.bitLockerRecoveryPasswordRotationDescrip: This setting initiates a client-driven recovery password rotation after an OS drive recovery (either by using bootmgr or WinRE).
SettingDetails.bitLockerRemovableDriveSettingsDescripti: These settings apply specifically to removable data drives. These settings only apply to Windows 10/11 Enterprise, Windows 10/11 Education and Windows 10 Mobile.
SettingDetails.bitLockerRemovableDriveWriteAccessCrossO: Determine if removable data-drives configured by an external organization can be written to.
Write access to devices configured in another organization
SettingDetails.bitLockerRemovableDriveWriteAccessDescri: Determine whether BitLocker protection is required for removable data-drives to be writable on a computer.
SettingDetails.bitLockerRemovableDriveWriteAccessName: Write access to removable data-drive not protected by BitLocker
SettingDetails.bitLockerRemovableEncryptionMethodDescri: AES-CBC algorithm is recommended if the removable drive will be used with other devices that are not running Windows 10 (Version 1511+).
SettingDetails.bitLockerSyntheticFixedDrivePolicyDriveR: Block the use of data recovery agent with BitLocker-protected fixed drives Policy Editor.

Control how BitLocker-protected fixed data-drives are recovered in the absence of the required startup key information. Selecting "Enable" allows you to configure various drive recovery techniques. By selecting "Not configured", the default recovery options are supported including DRA, the end user can specify recovery options and recovery information is not backed up to Microsoft Entra ID.
SettingDetails.bitLockerSyntheticSystemDrivePolicyDrive: Block the use of data recovery agent with BitLocker-protected OS drives Policy Editor.

Control how BitLocker-protected OS drives are recovered in the absence of the required startup key information. Selecting "Enable" allows you to configure various drive recovery techniques. By selecting "Not configured", the default recovery options are supported including DRA, the end user can specify recovery options and recovery information is not backed up to Microsoft Entra ID.
SettingDetails.bitLockerSystemDriveMiniumPinLengthDescr: Startup PINs can range between 4-20 digits in length.
SettingDetails.bitLockerSystemDriveMiniumPinLengthEnabl: Selecting "Enable" allows you to configure the minimum startup PIN length. If left "Not configured" and a TPM PIN is required, the default value will be 6 characters.
SettingDetails.bitLockerSystemDrivePrebootRecoveryCusto: Replace the default recovery URL that is displayed in the pre-boot BitLocker recovery screen.
SettingDetails.bitLockerSystemDrivePrebootRecoveryEnabl: Enable the recovery message and URL that are displayed on the pre-boot key recovery screen.
SettingDetails.bitLockerSystemDrivePrebootRecoveryMsgUR: Use default recovery message and URL
Configure the option for the pre-boot recovery message.
Use empty recovery message and URL
SettingDetails.bitLockerSystemDriveSettingsDescription: These settings apply specifically to operating system data drives. These settings only apply to Windows 10/11 Enterprise, Windows 10/11 Education and Windows 10 Mobile.
SettingDetails.bitLockerSystemDriveStartupAuthenticatio: Block the use of BitLocker on a computer without a compatible TPM chip.
BitLocker with non-compatible TPM chip
Selecting "Require" allows you to configure the additional authentication requirements at system start up, including utilizing the use of Trusted Platform Module (TPM) or startup PIN requirements.
Additional authentication at startup

SettingDetails.bitLockerWindowsSettingsDescription: These encryption settings apply to all versions of Windows 10 and later.
SettingDetails.bitLockerXTSAESEncryptionMethodDescripti: XTS-AES algorithm is recommended. Note: Changing the encryption method has no effect if the drive is already encrypted, or if encryption is in progress.
SettingDetails.bitlockerWarningInfoBox: Note: devices enabled with automatic encryption will require decryption before changing encryption method.
SettingDetails.blockAccessToAboutFlagsDescription: Users can access the about:flags page in Microsoft Edge, to change developer settings and enable experimental features. Select No, to block access to about:flags page.
SettingDetails.blockAddNewPrintersDescription: Prevent user installation of additional printers from printers settings.
SettingDetails.blockAddingAccountsDescription: Manage whether users can add or remove work profile accounts in the Settings app. Note that this does not affect the accounts that are automatically added in Settings when a user enrolls, or accounts entered directly into work apps.
SettingDetails.blockAdultContentInItunesDescription: Block explicit iTunes music, podcast, or news content. For supervised devices as of iOS 13.0.
SettingDetails.blockAdultContentInItunesName: Block playback of explicit music, podcast, and iTunes U
SettingDetails.blockAirPrintCredentialsStorageDescripti: Blocks keychain storage of username and password. Available with iOS 11.0 and later.
SettingDetails.blockAirPrintCredentialsStorageName: Block storage of AirPrint credentials in Keychain
SettingDetails.blockAirPrintiBeaconDiscoveryDescription: Blocking prevents malicious AirPrint BlueTooth beacons phishing for network traffic. Available with iOS 11.0 and later.
Blocking prevents malicious AirPrint Bluetooth beacons phishing for network traffic
SettingDetails.blockAirPrintiBeaconDiscoveryNameIOS: Block iBeacon discovery of AirPrint printers
SettingDetails.blockAirPrintiBeaconDiscoveryNameMacOS: Block discovery of AirPrint printers using iBeacons
SettingDetails.blockAntiTheftModeDescription: Block user from selecting AntiTheft mode preference
SettingDetails.blockAppClipsDescription: If you block app clips, users won't be allowed to add them to their devices, and their existing app clips will be removed. Available for devices running iOS and iPadOS versions 14.0 or later.
SettingDetails.blockAppStoreAutoUpdateDescription: Specifies whether apps from the Windows Store can automatically update.
SettingDetails.blockAppStoreAutomaticDownloadsDescripti: Blocks automatic downloading of apps purchased on other devices. Does not affect updates to existing apps.
SettingDetails.blockAppStoreDescription: For supervised devices as of iOS 13.0.
SettingDetails.blockAppStoreUIAppInstallationDescriptio: Block App Store from Home Screen. Users may continue to use iTunes or Apple Configurator to install or update apps.
SettingDetails.blockAppStoreUIAppInstallationName: Block installing apps using App Store
SettingDetails.blockAppleWatchAutoUnlockDescription: Blocks users from unlocking their Mac with Apple Watch.
SettingDetails.blockAppsFromSendingEmailDescription: Block the user from sending email from third party applications
SettingDetails.blockAppsFromSendingEmailName: Sending email from third party applications
SettingDetails.blockAppsInstallFromUnknownSourcesDescri: Block user from turning on unknown sources
SettingDetails.blockAppsInstallFromUnknownSourcesName: Block user from turning on unknown sources
SettingDetails.blockBluetoothAdvertisingDescription: Specifies whether the device can act as a source for Bluetooth advertisements and be discoverable to other devices.
SettingDetails.blockBluetoothDescription: Block bluetooth connections to and from the device.
SettingDetails.blockBluetoothDiscoverableModeDescriptio: Specifies whether other Bluetooth devices like a headset would be discoverable to the device.
SettingDetails.blockBluetoothModificationDescription: Block modification of Bluetooth settings. Available with iOS 11.0 or later.
SettingDetails.blockBluetoothPrepairingDescription: Specifies whether to allow specific bundled Bluetooth peripherals to automatically pair with the host device.
SettingDetails.blockCameraDescriptionMacOS: Blocks users from taking photographs and videos.
SettingDetails.blockCellularAppDataModificationDescript: Block changes to app cellular data usage settings.
SettingDetails.blockCellularAppDataModificationName: Block changes to app cellular data usage settings
SettingDetails.blockCellularPlanModificationName: Block changes to cellular plan settings
SettingDetails.blockClassroomAppRemoteScreenObservation: Block remote screen observation by Classroom app. This setting isn't available if screen capture is blocked. Available with iOS 9.3 or later.
Block remote AirPlay, view screen by Classroom app, and screen sharing
SettingDetails.blockClipboardAndroidDescription: Block clipboard sharing between apps (Samsung KNOX Standard 4.0+).
SettingDetails.blockClipboardName: Clipboard sharing between apps (Samsung KNOX only)
SettingDetails.blockConnectedDevicesServiceDescription: Specifies whether to allow the connected devices service which enables discovery and connection to other devices.
SettingDetails.blockControlCenterInLockScreenName: Block Control Center access in lock screen
SettingDetails.blockCookiesDescriptionIOS: Companies use cookies to track browsing history, and they can track browsing across multiple websites. By default, Apple allows all cookies, and blocks cross site tracking. Use this setting to allow users to enable or disable these features. Available on iOS and iPadOS versions 4 and later.
SettingDetails.blockCopyPasteBetweenWorkAndPersonalProf: Block copy from work to personal profile
SettingDetails.blockCrossProfileCallerIdDescription: Display work contact caller-id in personal profile
SettingDetails.blockCrossProfileCallerIdName: Display work contact caller-id in personal profile
SettingDetails.blockCrossProfileContactsSearchDescripti: Search work profile contacts from personal profile.
SettingDetails.blockCrossProfileContactsSearchName: Search work contacts from personal profile
SettingDetails.blockCrossProfileCopyPasteDescription: This setting controls whether or not apps in the work profile are allowed to share data with apps in the personal profile through copy and paste actions.
SettingDetails.blockCrossProfileCopyPasteName: Copy and paste between work and personal profiles
SettingDetails.blockCustomEmailDescription: Allow the device to sync with Custom email accounts
SettingDetails.blockDataRoamingAndroidDescription: Block data roaming over the cellular network (Samsung KNOX Standard 4.0+).
SettingDetails.blockDataRoamingDescription: Block data roaming over the cellular network.
SettingDetails.blockDefinitionLookupDescriptionMacOS: Block look up, a feature that looks up the definition of a highlighted word.
SettingDetails.blockDeveloperToolsDescription: Users can access the develop tools in Microsoft Edge. Select No, to block access to developer tools.
SettingDetails.blockDeviceDiscoveryDescription: Block device discovery by other devices
SettingDetails.blockDeviceEnablingRestrictionsDescripti: On iOS 12.0 or later, this blocks users from setting their own Screen Time settings, which includes device restrictions. On iOS 11.4.1 and earlier, this blocks the user from enabling restrictions in the device settings. The blocking effect is the same on any supervised iOS device.
SettingDetails.blockDeviceEraseContentAndSettingsDescri: Block the use of the erase all content and settings option on the device.
SettingDetails.blockDeviceEraseContentAndSettingsIosDes: Disables the reset option on supervised devices. Available for devices running iOS/iPadOS versions 8 and later.
SettingDetails.blockDeviceEraseContentAndSettingsIosNam: Block users from erasing all content and settings on device
SettingDetails.blockDeviceEraseContentAndSettingsMacOsD: Disables the reset option on supervised devices. Available for devices running macOS versions 12 and later.
SettingDetails.blockDeviceEraseContentAndSettingsMacOsN: Block users from erasing all content and settings on device
SettingDetails.blockDeviceEraseContentAndSettingsName: Block use of erase all content and settings
SettingDetails.blockDeviceNameModificationDescription: Block device name from being changed.
SettingDetails.blockDiagnosticDataSubmissionDescription: Block the device from sending diagnostic and usage telemetry data.
SettingDetails.blockDiagnosticDataSubmissionModificatio: Block the modification of the diagnostic submission and app analytics settings in the Diagnostics and Usage pane in Settings. This setting isn't available if sharing usage data is blocked. Available with iOS 9.3.2 or later.
SettingDetails.blockDoNotTrackHeaderDescription: Block device from sending do-not-track headers to websites requesting tracking info.
SettingDetails.blockESIMModificationDescription: Block the modification of eSIM settings.
SettingDetails.blockEdgeBrowserDescription: Microsoft Edge browser is allowed on mobile devices. Select No, to block Edge on mobile.
SettingDetails.blockEmailMessageMoveDescription: Block moving email messages between different email accounts.
SettingDetails.blockEmailMessageMoveName: Moving messages to other email accounts
SettingDetails.blockEnterpriseAppTrustDescription: Removes the Trust Enterprise Developer button in Settings->General->Profiles & Device Management.
SettingDetails.blockEnterpriseAppTrustModificationDescr: Block the changing of enterprise app trust settings.
SettingDetails.blockEnterpriseAppTrustName: Block trusting new enterprise app authors
SettingDetails.blockEnterpriseBookMetadataSyncName: Block notes and highlights sync for enterprise books
SettingDetails.blockExtensionsDescription: Users are allowed to add or personalize extensions in Microsoft Edge. Select No, to block users from modifying extensions.

SettingDetails.complianceRequiredPasswordTypeTrimmedDes: Recommendations:  Required password type: Alphanumeric, Minimum number of character sets: 1

Not supported by Android 8.0 and later). Important: To side-load apps, Unknown sources must be enabled. Enable this compliance policy only if you are not side-loading Android apps. Recommended value: Block

Most recent terms and conditions accepted

This setting determines the type of Password/PIN required.

Alphanumeric (Password or Alphanumberic PIN required)
